item.title: A Regulatory Strategy for Siting and Operating Waste Transfer Stations
item.description:
This report provides the findings of a 1999 National Environmental Justice Advisory Council study researching the impacts that waste transfer stations have on poor and minority communities, and reports the recommended actions for EPA to consider.

  • A Regulatory Strategy for Siting and Operating Waste Transfer Stations (PDF)(77 pp, 554 K, March 2000, EPA 500-R-00-001)

item.title: Preparing No-Migration Demonstrations for Municipal Solid Waste Disposal Facilities: A Screening Tool
item.description:
This guidance is intended to be a screening tool to be used by owners and operators of municipal solid waste landfils (MSWLFs) to rapidly determine their likelihood of preparing a successful no-migration demonstration. Such rapid screening is expected to save significant time and money when the MSWLF does not meet the applicable performance standards.

  • Preparing No-Migration Demonstrations for Municipal Solid Waste Disposal Facilities: A Screening Tool (PDF)(44 pp, 275 K, February 1999, EPA530-R-99-008)
    EPA's established guidance to enable the owner or operator of a MSWLF to pursue the early decision-making stages of a no-migration demonstration as efficiently and inexpensively as possible.
item.dc:creator: eocampo

item.title: Criteria for Solid Waste Disposal Facilities: A Guide for Owners/Operators
item.description:
To make waste management more effective, federal, state, tribal and local governments adopted an integrated approach to waste management. This strategic approach involves a mix of the following three waste management techniques:

  • Decreasing the amount and/or toxicity of waste that must be disposed of by producing less waste to begin with (source reduction)
  • Increasing recycling of materials such as paper, glass, steel, plastic and aluminum, thus recovering these materials rather than discarding them
  • Providing safer disposal capacity by improving the design and management of incinerators and landfills
  • Criteria for Solid Waste Disposal Facilities: A Guide for Owners/Operators (PDF)(22 pp, 2 MB, March 1993, EPA/530-SW-91-089)
    EPAs continuing mission to establish the minimum national standards for landfill design, operation, and management that will enhance landfill safety and boost public confidence in landfills as a component of a workable integrated waste management system.

item.title: Subpart E-Groundwater Monitoring and Corrective Action
item.description:
This criteria establishes groundwater monitoring and corrective action requirements for all existing and new municipal solid waste landfill units, as well as lateral expansions of existing units. The criteria includes requirements for the location, design and installation of groundwater monitoring systems and set standards for groundwater sampling and analysis.

  • Subpart E-Groundwater Monitoring and Corrective Action (PDF)(114 pp, 610 K, April 2012)
    Provides specific statistical methods and decision criteria for identifying a significant change in ground-water quality.

item.title: Bioreactor Performance
item.description:
EPA's research and demonstration studies for bioreactor landfills which showed that a landfill using leachate recirculation can be designed and operated to increase the rate of waste stabilization. This process significantly increases the rate of biodegradation of the waste (similar to anaerobic composting), thereby reducing the waste stabilization period from 5 to 10 years instead of 30 or more years for a conventional “dry tomb” designed facility.

  • Bioreactor Performance (PDF)(28 pp, 174 K, August 15, 2007, EPA530-R-07-007)
    Describes how leachate head maintenance, settlement, side slope stability, fire prevention, and gas collection were designed to protect human health and the environment at the five sites described in Section 4 and if any system enhancements were implemented after initial startup that improved operations.

item.title: Landfill Reclamation
item.description:
Landfill reclamation is used to expand municipal solid waste landfill capacity, and avoid the high cost of acquiring additional land. Reclamation costs are often offset by the sale or use of recovered materials, such as recyclables, soil and waste, which can be burned as fuel. Other important benefits may include avoided liability through site remediation, reductions in closure costs, and reclamation of land for other uses.

  • Landfill Reclamation (PDF)(8 pp, 96 K, July 1997, EPA530-F-97-001)
    EPA's fact sheet describes new and innovative technologies and products that meet the performance standards of the Criteria for Municipal Solid Waste Landfills (40 CFR Part 258).

item.title: Geo-synthetic Clay Liners Used in Municipal Solid Waste Landfills
item.description:
Geo-synthetic clay liners (GCLs) provides a barrier system in municipal solid waste landfill applications. Federal and some state regulations specify design standards for bottom liner-sand final covers. GCL technology is an alternative that performs at or above standard federal performance levels.

  • Geosynthetic Clay Liners Used in Municipal Solid Waste Landfills (PDF)(8 pp, 114 K, Revised December 2001, EPA530-F-97-002)
    EPA's fact sheet describes new and innovative technologies and products that meet the performance standards of the Criteria for Municipal Solid Waste Landfills (40 CFR Part 258).

item.title: Waste Transfer Stations: A Manual for Decision-Making
item.description:
This manual defines what a waste transfer station is and how it relates to municipal solid waste management in the context of a community’s total waste management plan.

  • Waste Transfer Stations: A Manual for Decision-Making (PDF)(66 pp, 523 K, June 2002, EPA530-R-02-002)
    Identifies issues and factors to consider when deciding to build a transfer station, planning and designing it, selecting a site, and involving the community.

item.title: Waste Transfer Stations: Involved Citizens Make the Difference
item.description:
Waste transfer stations make solid waste collection more efficient and reduce overall transportation costs, air emissions,
energy use, truck traffic, and road wear and tear. This saves you and your community money, as well as lowers the cost of your solid waste management services.

  • Waste Transfer Stations: Involved Citizens Make the Difference (PDF)(29 pp, 209 K, January 2001, EPA530-K-01-003)
    Provides key information involved citizens will need to develop an opinion about a proposed or modified transfer station. Also provides ideas on how to get involved to enhance the value of the waste transfer station.
